image.altText: Australia batter Pat Cummins shouts in joy after winning an Ashes Test at Edgbaston.

items.synopsis: Pat Cummins leads Australia to a stunning victory in the first Ashes Test, chasing down 281 with just two wickets left inside the final five overs at Edgbaston.

title.children: Pat Cummins leads Australia to miraculous Ashes victory with thrilling run chase at Edgbaston

image.altText: A lady at the foot of the mountains outside her property

items.synopsis: Commercial kangaroo shooters are regulated under a national code that's supposed to protect animal welfare, but activists say what happens in rural Australia at night can be in breach of it, putting the industry under threat.

title.children: 'We are frightened in our own home': Jane is part of a growing campaign to stop kangaroo culling

image.altText: Lea Russ lying in a hospital bed, with multiple IV tubes hooked up to one arm.

items.synopsis: Patients who need to see a GP urgently are increasingly waiting more than 24 hours to be seen. But they may not know that general practices are meant to offer emergency bookings.

title.children: Getting an urgent GP appointment can be hard, but a little-known rule means it shouldn't be

image.altText: England fielder Ben Stokes drops the ball as he hits the ground.

items.synopsis: Australia wins a thrilling Ashes Test to gain an early advantage over England and the Bazball phenomena. Here are the main talking points from an enthralling day of cricket.

title.children: Five quick hits — Ben Stokes grabs the game by the scruff of the neck  … and then drops it

image.altText: A bald man looks at someone off-camera with a serious look

items.synopsis: Alleged threats made to a mental health consultant by Victorian government officials should be investigated by the state's human rights commission, according to the state opposition.

title.children: Anti-discrimination watchdog called on to 'urgently' investigate alleged threats made by Victorian government

image.altText: Daniel Andrews looks happy in a suit

items.synopsis: Victorian politicians are set to receive a 3.5 per cent pay rise from next month following a decision by an independent tribunal that has drawn criticism.

title.children: Daniel Andrews remains highest-paid premier as Victorian MPs receive 3.5pc pay rise

image.altText: A middle-aged man in jeans and a jacket sits in a chair and smiles. In front is a table with Titanic Expedition written on it

items.synopsis: A renowned Titanic expert, a world-record-holding adventurer, two members of one of Pakistan's wealthiest families and the CEO of the company leading an expedition to the world's most famous shipwreck are facing critical danger aboard a small submersible that has gone missing in the Atlantic Ocean.

title.children: A Titanic expert, an adventurer, a father and his son and a CEO: These are the people on the missing submersible

image.altText: A cylindrical white metal underwater craft floats in a dark blue mass of water.

items.synopsis: Search efforts are continuing for five people missing in a deep-ocean submersible in the northern Atlantic, with rescuers in a race against time as oxygen levels dwindle.

title.children: All passengers on board missing Titanic submersible identified as breathable air dwindles

image.altText: A black and white photo of a man with a guitar and a white shirt with blood stains

items.synopsis: An inquiry hears a NSW Police task force ruled there was "insufficient information" to establish whether the former AC/DC manager's death was a hate crime but it had not tested his blood-stained clothes.

title.children: Bloody clothes left untested by police for 30 years could solve mystery of who killed AC/DC manager

image.altText: Ice

items.synopsis: A Tasmanian inquiry hears disturbing accounts of children being injected and given ice by parents wanting them to commit crimes.

title.children: 'You poor little thing': Parents injecting kids with ice to commit crimes, inquiry hears

image.altText: A rainbow-coloured sign advertising the cancellation of an event.

items.synopsis: When organisers first convinced traditionally conservative parts of the country to host a Pride ball, it was celebrated as a win for inclusion. Now thriving, these events are increasingly facing a new and sinister threat.

title.children: Far right groups and conspiracy theorists forcing shutdowns of pride events in growing trend

image.altText: Yunupingu with Gumatj children at Garma in 2019.

items.synopsis: Late Gumatj clan leader Yunupingu won a historic legal battle that could have significant implications for compensation claims across Australia. The Commonwealth is now appealing.

title.children: Commonwealth lodges High Court challenge to landmark $700 million native title compensation claim

image.altText: Signage at a Telstra store in Sydney.

items.synopsis: It has been red across the board on global markets, with China's rate cut disappointing and traders awaiting testimony from the Federal Reserve chair. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Telstra-TPG regional network deal blocked, ASX in the red

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian Competition Tribunal has upheld the ACCC's decision last year to block a regional network sharing agreement between TPG and Telstra. Here's some more details of the Tribunal's reasoning from the ACCC : The Tribunal denied authorisation because it was not satisfied that the proposed arrangements were not likely to have the effect of a substantial lessening of competition or that the benefit to the public likely to result would outweigh the detriment. The Tribunal noted that the proposed arrangements would give Telstra substantial benefits and increase its market strength on the retail and wholesale mobile markets, and would undermine Optus' incentives to invest in 5G technology. Over time, this would weaken the competitive constraint on Telstra, and lead to increased prices and margins. The Tribunal found that "the Spectrum Authorisation Agreement provides Telstra with substantial commercial and competitive benefits and would further increase Telstra's position of market strength in mobile telecommunications markets." Understandably, Telstra and TPG aren't too happy that their deal remains blocked and are reviewing their options. On the other hand, Optus is very pleased, calling it "a win for Australians". "We are delighted that the Tribunal has upheld the ACCC’s original decision to block this anti-competitive arrangement," said Optus boss Kelly Bayer Rosmarin. "This reinforces the importance of infrastructure-based competition and investment in our communications sector that will have lasting benefits for regional Australia. "This is a good outcome for our regional communities as it will mean they will continue to benefit from competition as Optus reaffirms its commitment to providing Australia’s regional communities with a strong network and great service." Optus expects to spend $1.6 billion on infrastructure and services investment this year. In its statement to the market today, TPG reaffirmed its earnings guidance for the current financial year. It also said if the Telstra agreement ultimately does not proceed it may adjust its future capital expenditure plans "for higher short-term investment at sites within its existing regional network" which would've been decommissioned or transferred under the arrangement.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: TPG deal would've increased Telstra's market strength: Tribunal

Australian Competition Tribunal
has upheld the ACCC's decision last year to block a regional network sharing agreement between
TPG

ACCC
The Tribunal denied authorisation because it was
not satisfied that the proposed arrangements were not likely to have the effect of a substantial lessening of competition
or that the benefit to the public likely to result would outweigh the detriment.
The Tribunal noted that the proposed arrangements would
give Telstra substantial benefits and increase its market strength
on the retail and wholesale mobile markets, and
would undermine Optus' incentives to invest in 5G technology
. Over time, this would weaken the competitive constraint on Telstra, and lead to increased prices and margins.
The Tribunal found that "the Spectrum Authorisation Agreement provides Telstra with substantial commercial and competitive benefits and
would further increase Telstra's position of market strength
in mobile telecommunications markets."
Understandably, Telstra and TPG aren't too happy that their deal remains blocked and are reviewing their options.
On the other hand,
Optus
is very pleased, calling it "a win for Australians".
"We are delighted that the Tribunal has upheld the ACCC’s original decision to block this anti-competitive arrangement," said Optus boss
Kelly Bayer Rosmarin
"This reinforces the importance of infrastructure-based competition and investment in our communications sector that will have lasting benefits for regional Australia.

"This is a good outcome for our regional communities as it will mean they will continue to benefit from competition as Optus reaffirms its commitment to providing Australia’s regional communities with a strong network and great service."
Optus expects to spend $1.6 billion on infrastructure and services investment this year.
In its statement to the market today, TPG reaffirmed its earnings guidance for the current financial year.

It also said if the Telstra agreement ultimately does not proceed it may adjust its future capital expenditure plans "for higher short-term investment at sites within its existing regional network" which would've been decommissioned or transferred under the arrangement.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian Competition Tribunal has upheld a decision to block a network sharing agreement between major telcos Telstra and TPG. The deal would've seen TPG decommission or transfer regional mobile sites, and then acquire mobile services from Telstra. TPG says it would've increased its mobile network coverage from 96 per cent to 98.8 per cent of the Australian population. At the end of last year, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission rejected the plans, arguing there was a real risk it would reduce investment in infrastructure. Telstra and TPG challenged the decision but now the Australian Competition Tribunal has upheld it. "This determination entrenches the status quo for mobile coverage in regional Australia," TPG boss Iñaki Berroeta said today. TPG is now considering its options for a further appeal. At the time it blocked the sharing deal, the ACCC said there would be some short-term benefits in improving TPG's network coverage, but that it could lessen infrastructure-based competition. "Competition between separate mobile networks drives companies to improve coverage for mobile users and to offer new technologies to more areas. "For example, when Optus improves its regional network, Telstra responds by improving its network to maintain its market position," ACCC Commissioner Liza Carver said in December. "Infrastructure competition is what drives investments by mobile companies in broader, deeper and faster mobile coverage… We have concluded the proposed arrangements would likely significantly weaken this competitive process."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: TPG - Telstra regional network sharing deal blocked

children.content: The
Australian Competition Tribunal
has upheld a decision to block a network sharing agreement between major telcos
Telstra
and
TPG.
The deal would've seen TPG decommission or transfer regional mobile sites, and then acquire mobile services from Telstra.
TPG says it would've increased its mobile network coverage from 96 per cent to 98.8 per cent of the Australian population.
At the end of last year, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission rejected the plans, arguing there was a real risk it would reduce investment in infrastructure.
Telstra and TPG challenged the decision but now the Australian Competition Tribunal has upheld it.
"This determination entrenches the status quo for mobile coverage in regional Australia," TPG boss Iñaki Berroeta said today.
TPG is now considering its options for a further appeal.
At the time it blocked the sharing deal, the ACCC said there would be some short-term benefits in improving TPG's network coverage, but that it could lessen infrastructure-based competition.
"Competition between separate mobile networks drives companies to improve coverage for mobile users and to offer new technologies to more areas.
"For example, when Optus improves its regional network, Telstra responds by improving its network to maintain its market position," ACCC Commissioner Liza Carver said in December.

"Infrastructure competition is what drives investments by mobile companies in broader, deeper and faster mobile coverage… We have concluded the proposed arrangements would likely significantly weaken this competitive process."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's early days for the local session but the share market has so far lost ground, with the All Ordinaries down around 0.3 per cent. There are some falls for iron ore miners, including a 2 per cent drop for Fortescue shares. This morning Fortescue updated the market, saying executive chairman Andrew Forrest had transferred ownership of around $5 billion worth of shares (220 million FMG shares) to his philanthropic venture, the Minderoo Foundation — that's one-fifth of the family's holding in the miner. Gold mining stocks are also under pressure, including Silver Lake Resources (-4%). And TPG Telecom shares have slumped more than 8 per cent on news the Australian Competition Tribunal has blocked a regional network sharing arrangement with Telstra. Telstra shares are up 0.6 per cent. It's a better session for consumer stocks, with some retailers on the rise including Woolworths (+0.7%) and Coles (+0.9%). Here's how the sectors are faring:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX in the red in early trade
